titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Yale Miscellaneous Manuscripts Collection
titlestmt.author: compiled by staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:36

did.unittitle: Yale Miscellaneous Manuscripts collection

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: An artificial collection of correspondence, writings, diaries, and memorabilia relating to Yale University, its officials and employees, faculty, students, and related topics.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Yale Miscellaneous Manuscripts Collection (MS 1258). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Yale Miscellaneous Manuscript No. 77, Warner Thornton McGuinn scrapbook relating to politics and civil rights in Baltimore, Maryland, 1901-1918 is available on microfilm (157 frames on 1 reel, 35mm.) from Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library, at cost. Order no. HM198.

Nathaniel W. Taylor's journal of a voyage to Hurd's Island, 1857-1859, in Series I, is available on microfilm (66 frames on 1 reel, 35 mm.) from Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library, at cost. Order no. HM268.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in two series: I. Alphabetical (by author). II. Numerical (by order of acquisition).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Yale Miscellaneous Manuscripts is a collection of material which pertains primarily to Yale and its graduates, and includes such items as correspondence, diaries, writings, and memorabilia. The collection spans the entire history of Yale; a significant portion of the holdings dates from the eighteenth century.
The collection consists of two series. Series I is arranged alphabetically by author. Series II is arranged numerically in order of acquisition.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Robert U. Redpath III and his son, Ian D. W. Redpath, retain to themselves during their lifetimes all copyright and other property rights that they may have in the papers and other materials donated to the Yale University Library until their deaths or April 9, 2058, whichever occurs first, after which these rights will become the property of Yale University Library. (Series II. Numerical. box 73, item no. 292).

Randall Alfred transferred to Yale University any copyright and other property rights he may have for any unpublished materials he may have authored or otherwise produced. (Series II. Numerical. box 73, item no. 299).

Jean R. Becton and William M. Redpath transferred to Yale University any copyright and other property rights they have in the unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by Robert U. Redpath. (Series II. Numerical. box 74, item no. 301).

Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lorrin Shepard graduated from Yale College in 1914 and from Columbia Medical School in 1917. Following their marriage in 1919, he and his wife, Virginia, sailed to Turkey, where they worked with the Near East Relief unit in Aintab (now Gaziantep) providing medical services to Armenian refugees and others. The letters, written by the Shepards to family and friends, describe medical relief efforts in Turkey during the Turkish War of Independence (1919-1923), the Turkish-Armenian War (1920), and the ongoing genocide against Armenians in the crumbling Ottoman Empire following World War I. Shepard served as the director of the American Hospital in Istanbul from 1927-1957. At Yale, following their return from Turkey, he served as director of the International Student Center from 1957-1959, and as Assistant to the University Secretary from 1959 until his retirement in 1963.

No. 170: Patton, John (1850-1907): ALS to Miles W. Tate of Tionesta, Pennsylvania with observations on current events and life at Yale College
No. 171: Twistle, Timothy, Pseud. Ms, "Farrago libelli or the speculations of a Sophomore. No.1 By Timothy Twistle, Principal Editor"

No. 172: Holden, Daniel Judson (1844-1903): 110 ALS chiefly written to his sister, Katherine J. Holden while Daniel J. Holden was a student at Yale College. In addition to accounts of his studies and student life, there are references to the Civil War, among them a draft among students at Yale College in 1863 and expected riots in New Haven. There is also an account of a walking tour from New Haven to Boston in 1964. With a typewritten transcript, prefaced by an explanatory note (1957) by the writer's daughter, Edith Holden. Her father's picture, copied from the Yale Class Album of 1864, is also included
No. 173: Carroll, Douglas Gordon (1915-1977): TMS (copy), diaries 1929-1947, including those for his years at Yale College, 1933-1938

No. 174: Hayman, Ike, of Rutherford, N.J., collector: "Yale men who served on the bench of the United States Supreme Court," a collection of portraits and autographs, written 1790-1951, comprising 13 portraits and thirteen manuscripts.

No. 175: Pelikan, Jaroslav Jan (1923-): TMS (electrostatic copy) "Yale's collections - A national treasure." An address to Assembly XX of the Association of Yale Alumni, on April 1, 1982 by Jaroslav Pelikan, Sterling Professor of History
No. 176: Bridgewater, Dorothy W: TMS, "The Yale Library of 1742."

No. 177: Stetson, Charles Pierce (1835-1899): Letters to Charles P. Stetson from his sister, Anna Maria, and from a friend, Franklin A. Wilson at Bowdoin College, comparing it with Yale College. Also a notice of his election to the Yale Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa in 1854
No. 178: Coe, Henry Clarke (1856-1940): ALS to "My dear Cleveland" inviting him to speak on "medical men and 'medical preparedness'" at a meeting of the M.R.C. Association

No. 179: Sander, Anton (1851-1881): 34 ALS to his friend, O.G. Felland, with whom he had been a student at Luther College in Decorah, Iowa. Most of the letters are from Yale College (1875-1877) where Sander was studying from his Ph.D. The remaining letters (1878-1880) are from various teaching posts in Lawrenceville, New Jersey, Decorah, Iowa and Flusing, New York. Included also is an obiturary on Sander's death from a Norwegian newspaper published in Decorah, Iowa (1881 Jan 27) with an English translation

No. 180: Mallery, Garrick (1831-1894): Army officer and ethnologist. Autograph album and manuscript diary (2 copies) kept during his last two years at Yale College (1849-1850); essays on the Mormons and Chinese in California, on American Indians and an incomplete letter, probably to his father, describing a trip on a steamboat on the Missouri
No. 181: Taft, Horace Dutton (1861-1943): 2 ALS to Sarah Jarvis (Brush) McLaughlin on the occasion of the death of her husband, Edward Tompkins McLaughlin
No. 182: Pardee, Joseph Harvey (1818-1868): ALS to Romeo Lowrey while a student at Yale College on a matter of discipline
No. 183: Seropyan, Christopher Dicran (1825-1874): ALS to Munroe & Co. in Boston ordering twelve copies of the Oration of Demosthenes on the Crown

No. 184: Nichols, Alfred Bull (1852-1913): 42 ALS to Edward P. Noyes, mostly written while Nicholas was a tutor in German at Yale College (1884-1887) and later while traveling and studying in Germany (1888-1890). His comments from Berlin on German life and politics, particularly on the brief region of Frederick III, with a vivid portrait of the hostile public attitude toward the Empress are of particular interest. Included also are several letters by others to members of the Noyes family and a carte de visite photograph of Benjamin W. Dwight

No. 185: Thorneycroft, Thomas (1822-1903)(compiler): Scrapbook titled, "Mr. Spitzer's Visit to England, August 1899. Presented by Lieut.-Col. Thorneycroft, Tettenhall Towers." It contains photographs, manuscript essays and poetry, clippings, drawings, pamphlets and other printed matter, music and memorabilia, most of it pertaining to Thorneycroft, his family and his estate.

No. 186: Commonplace-book (ca. 1803): Transcriptions of poems, epitaphs and the texts of songs, some referring to Yale College. Included is a copy of The Yaliad by Cyrus Pearce, poems by Dr. [Timothy] Dwight and John Trumbull and songs composed in connection with a Republican meeting in New Haven

No. 187: Babcock, Thorpe (1885-1979): TMS (carbon copy), "Chuck Lambert of Yale." Enclosure: 2 ms pages by the author's sister, Corinne Babcock. A fictionalized autobiography of the author's life after graduation from Yale
No. 188: Brady, Richard J.: Stalag - Luft III, Bob Neary, 1946; scrapbook of photographs, clippings, & cables

No. 191: Chadwick, George Brewster: Letters
No. 192: Knapp, Jared (1816-1818): Letters
No. 193: McGregor, Donald Rait (1906-): Christmas Magic: song ms (photocopy) words and music

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Robert U. Redpath III and his son, Ian D. W. Redpath, retain to themselves during their lifetimes all copyright and other property rights that they may have in the papers and other materials donated to the Yale University Library until their deaths or April 9, 2058, whichever occurs first, after which these rights will become the property of Yale University Library.

No. 299: Alfred, Randall, papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Randy Alfred's papers include correspondence, fliers, clippings, and event programs that document the struggle in 1981 to get the Yale Alumni Magazine's Class Notes to use the word "gay" and to treat communications from all classmates without bias based on sexual orientation. Also documented is the Class of 1967's hosting in 1982 of alumni from all classes for the first official LGBT reunion event.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A volume titled, "Log book of a thousand mile canoe trip", June 27 to August 1894, to Quebec and back to New Haven via steamer, railroad, and canoe. Created by George W. Mixter, 1895S, who participated with fellow Sheffield Scientific School classmates: Harry W. Foote, 1895S; Arthur Brewer, 1894S; Winchester Bennett, 1897S; and Edward S. Uhl, 1894S.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The album contains photographs of Scandinavian forests and silviculture. The majority are from Sweden, but Denmark and Norway are also represented.
